page.title: 20EARLY CRICKET
page.content: At Easter,1622 George Carleton, the Bishop of Chichester from 1617-1628 made each player confess and repent his wrong doings. The Crimes were, playing in the church yard, breaking the church windows with the ball and nearly beating out the brains of a little girl with a cricket bat. The last offence happened because in those days the rules allowed a batsman to hit the ball twice rather like the game 'peggy' played in Yorkshire. In this case one of the players hit a little girl standing nearby. The rules of the game were changed in 1647 after a fatality at Selsey. All the Boxgrove players were found guilty and fined XII d.(12d.) This was a lot of money and in addition they lost a days pay by having to walk in to Chichester. The players ages ranged from 16 to 36.
